BLIST.ITEM:
PBS Infinite Serieshttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCs4aHmggTfFrpkPcWSaBN9g
enHTMLhttps://www.youtube.com/feeds/videos.xml?channel_id=UCs4aHmggTfFrpkPcWSaBN9gRSS(Kelsey Houston-Edwards, Tai-Danae Bradley, Gabe Perez-Giz)

X.T: On Proof And Progress In Mathematics

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some thought about mathematicians, among them the fact that their job is not to prove theorems but to communicate ideas.
A further Web analysis: the Web appears to be a network ruled by a power-law distribution.

X.T: The Church-Turing Thesis: Story and Recent Progress

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The premises of Church-Turing thesis, the thesis itself and the current work on it (abstract state machines).
After a quick presentation of the algorithm, Peter Sanders presents some current uses and some possible future improvements to more complex problems.
Yoav Freund presents the random projection trees algorithm used to extract the few intrinsic dimensions in a highly-constrained high-dimensional system.

X.T: Demain : quel temps ? Un mathématicien en visite chez Chronos

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The presentation of some subjects more or less linked to time, but their presentation is very high level, so you have to know about them beforehand and, and the connection between the subjects is unclear.
It is a pity that, given the speaker, the level of the presentation is so low and the last part, which gets philosophical, could have been more interesting if it would have been better presented.

X.T: Des particules, des étoiles et des probabilités

ARTICLE.COMMENT: From the study of system solar stability to a proof of Landau damping.
A mathematical analysis of Dobble.

X.T: New Wikipedia sized proof explained with a puzzle

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Erdős discrepancy problem has been proved for C=2 using a computer.

X.T: The Most Difficult Program to Compute? - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Ackermann's function.

X.T: The Man Who Tried to Redeem the World with Logic
X.ST: Walter Pitts rose from the streets to MIT, but couldn’t escape himself.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The life of Walter Pitts who worked with Warren McCulloch, Jerome Lettvin, and Patrick Wall, to understand how the brain works.

X.T: In Mathematics, Mistakes Aren’t What They Used To Be
X.ST: Computers can’t invent, but they’re changing the field anyway.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using computers for mathematical demonstrations, in particular as proof assistants.

X.T: One-maths show ! Et si on parlait des maths ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Miscellaneous mathematical trivia.
How to build a hexaflexagon with three faces.

X.T: Hexaflexagones : la multiplication des faces - Micmaths

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to build a hexaflexagon with four faces.

X.T: Answer to a 150-Year-Old Math Conundrum Brings More Mystery

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Peter Keevash proved a major advance in block design.
A very simple triangle problem, but the proof that the center of mass is always at the same height is missing…

X.T: Heptadecagon and Fermat Primes (the math bit) - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Constructible angles and Fermat numbers.
The percentage of numbers containing 3 tends toward 100% when considering more and more numbers.
A trick to calculate fifth root in one's head.

X.T: How many chess games are possible?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Several persons tried to evaluate the number of possible chess games.
Some information about Martin Gardner.
The Fold and Cut theorem and its application to all letters of the alphabet.
Four paradoxes with infinity: Hilbert's hotel, Gabriel's trumpet, the puzzle of the dartboard, double your money.
Arranging 0, 1… 9 so there is no four digits in ascending or descending order.
Standard Young tables and Hook lengths.
The continuation of the previous video.
Tupper's self-referential formula.
Some well-known problems having a simple elegant solution: the mutilated chessboard, the sum of integers…
Moiré Patterns.

X.T: The Mathematics of Crime and Terrorism - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Hawkes Process.
Some information on Ramanujan's work on partitions.
The continuation of the previous video.
Trying to predict how to paperclips and two rubber bands will behave when placed on a strip of paper that is unfolded.
The continuation of the previous video.
Average waiting time to get heads-heads vs average waiting time to get heads-tails.

X.T: Riemann's paradox: pi = infinity minus infinity

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Riemann rearrangement theorem.

X.T: Top 5 des problèmes de maths simples mais non résolus - Micmaths

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Collatz conjecture, the Ramsey numbers, the Lychrel numbers, the chromatic number of the plane, and the multiplicative persistence.
How to compute the number of ways to choose 12 bagels when 4 flavours are available.

X.T: The Flaw in Reductio Ad Absurdum

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subject of provability is interesting, but the author does not master it and this video is just gibberish.

X.T: Ramanujan's infinite root and its crazy cousins

ARTICLE.COMMENT: About infinite expressions and the meaning of these.
The title says all.

X.T: How Many Humans Have the Same Number of Body Hairs? | Infinite Series | PBS Digital Studios

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Pigeonhole Principle.
Some very short scientific papers: a counter-example of Euler conjecture, Nash's seminal paper on game theory…

X.T: Can You Solve the Poison Wine Challenge? | Infinite Series | PBS Digital

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Very basic stuff, this is only about binary representations. It is a pity she gives the solution of the puzzle at the very beginning.

X.T: Can We Hear Shapes? | Infinite Series | PBS Digital Studios

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Can two different 2D shapes be isospectral?
Some examples of mathematical singularities in the real world.
Creating a real-world cycloid to demonstrate it is brachistochronous and tautochronous.
Trying to draw a 2D map of the different domains of mathematics.
An introduction, first, on Zermelo's theorem, then on infinite chess.
Gale-Shapley algorithm.
A presentation of some tools used in demonstrations by applying them in simple proofs.
Some properties of Pascal triangle.

X.T: Funny Fractions and Ford Circles - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to Farey Sequences and the (unexplained) fact that they appear in Ford circles.
The usual story about Gauss's integer sum and adding all the digits of numbers from 1 to 1000000.

X.T: Building an Infinite Bridge | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to stack bricks to get the longest overhang.
The history of Apéry's finding and how to evaluate it using random triplets of integers.
Cantor set and Cantor function.
The origins of the Arabic numerals.

X.T: The Impossible Mathematics of the Real World
X.ST: Near-miss math provides exact representations of almost-right answers.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some anecdotes of mathematical near-misses, but there is little explanation on how these can be exploited.

X.T: How to Cut Cake Fairly and Finally Eat It Too
X.ST: Computer scientists have come up with an algorithm that can fairly divide a cake among any number of people

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The algorithm may require {{{{n^n}^n}^n}^n}^n steps.

X.T: When do clock hands overlap? - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says alls.
A randomized extension of Ross-Littlewood Paradox.
Continued fractions and Khinchin's constant.
Theorizing juggling.

X.T: How to Generate Pseudorandom Numbers | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Two pseudorandom number algorithms (the middle-square algorithm and the linear congruential generator) and inverse transform sampling.

X.T: Crisis in the Foundation of Mathematics | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How mathematics build pieces on top of other pieces and a quick presentation of logicism.
Pancake sorting.
Different types of auction system and some comments about them.

X.T: La conjugaison complexe est un automorphisme de corps - Micmaths

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Explaining a non-trivial mathematical sentence.

X.T: Hilbert's 15th Problem: Schubert Calculus | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A quick presentation of Schubert Calculus and of a simple puzzle, but the relationship is not explained.
Loop concatenation is non-associative.

X.T: Associahedra: The Shapes of Multiplication | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous video. A fast-paced mind-boggling introduction to homotopy, associahedra, and Catalan Numbers.

X.T: Mickaël Launay : Le mystère de la farfalle - Tournée de Pi 2017

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some mathematical humor about pasta.
Some very simple calculation on kinetic energy.

X.T: How to Divide by "Zero" | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic introduction to quotient sets.

X.T: Telling Time on a Torus | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Finding out when clock hands could be exchanged and we would still get a valid hour, by using a torus shape.

X.T: The Geometry of SET | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using ℤ/nℤ to analyse Set (the game).
A simple clever calculation trick.

X.T: Solving 2D equations using color, a story of winding numbers and composition

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A colorful introduction to winding numbers.

X.T: Arithmetic mean vs Geometric mean | inequality among means | visual proof

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A visual proof that the geometric mean is smaller than the arithmetic mean.

X.T: [Hervé Lehning] Les mathématiques pour comprendre le monde

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Hervé Lehning is marketing his book with basic well known mathematics-anecdotes.
An elegant (but not rigorous) proof of the fact that, if a sphere is split in two parts of the same area, it is possible to find a pair of antipodal points, one in each part.

X.T: Universal Method to Sort Complex Information Found
X.ST: The nearest neighbor problem asks where a new point fits into an existing data set. A few researchers set out to prove that there was no universal way to solve it. Instead, they found such a way.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some progress has been done on the nearest neighbor problem, but the article gives little explanation on these recent papers.

X.T: A Proof About Where Symmetries Can’t Exist
X.ST: In a major mathematical achievement, a small team of researchers has proven Zimmer’s conjecture.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A proof of Zimmer's conjecture has been done, but this article cannot really describe such abstract mathematics.

X.T: Primes on the Moon (Lunar Arithmetic) - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of "lunar arithmetic" (previously known as "dismal arithmetic") and some properties of this one.
An algorithm for moving a knight surprisingly gives a very long but finite path.
The explanation of two mathematics pieces present in Futurama.
The continuation of the previous video.
Some simple rules, a rather complex problem and a simple solution.

X.T: Who Mourns the Tenth Heegner Number?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Heegner Numbers and the frustration when you spend a long time studying a mathematical object to finally discover that it does not exist.

X.T: How a Strange Grid Reveals Hidden Connections Between Simple Numbers
X.ST: A long-standing puzzle seems to constrain how addition and multiplication relate to each other. A graduate student has gone further than anyone else in establishing the connection.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the sum-product phenomenon.

X.T: Russell's Paradox - A Ripple in the Foundations of Mathematics

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Gottlob Frege's work and Bertrand Russell's paradox.

X.T: Why do things exist? Setting the stage for evolution.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Kind of analyzing two very simple population models.
Another way to analyze of the second model.
A first simple model involving mutation.
The fact that the resources are not infinite is now taken into account. This limits the total population.
Simulating a population with three traits: size, speed, and sense.
There is no simulation in this video, just a short description of three genes strategies: carrier-focused, win-win and altruistic.
